text: hello everyone I'm excited to be talking
on this stage today I want to talk to
you about instant observability for
communities without changing your code
or configurations using
pixie pixie is a cncf Sandbox project
since
2021 it is an open source platform built
for kubernetes observability for
developers and kues
administrators the unique thing about
pixie's platform is it is a completely
scriptable and apid driven
platform pixie captures all your in uh
all your Telemetry data without having
to do any manual
instrumentation it uses ebpf under the
hood to capture all your tmed data like
Network and resource metrics your HTTP
requests application profiling and much
much more and installing pixie takes
only five minutes all you have to do is
run PX Deploy on your cluster and you're
good to
go and pixie is fully
programmable everything is driven by
scripts all the scripts in pixie are
having a pythonic syntax and it fully
supports
pandas it was built with data analysis
and machine learning in
mind you get a bunch of scripts out of
the box when you install pixie but you
also have tons of community contributor
Scripts to help you get
started and best of all pixie is
kubernetes native pixie modules run
natively as demon said in your each of
your cluster nodes and all the data of
telemetry is stored in the memory of
cluster for up to 24
hours you can choose to export all or
selected data to an external long-term
storage you can view query or visualize
your data using pixie CLI pixie's live
UI or neic
platform the two main components which
help create pix's magic dust are pixie's
viia and pix's Edge
module pixie's Edge module is the main
component which deploys the BPF probes
within the Clusters and helps detect
helps capture the Telemetry data by
detecting the protocols like HTTP
database calls networking and
Communications and any other protocol
that you want to capture
with and all this tele data is queriable
from memory and all the operations are
still happening within your memory no
data leaves your cluster's
memory pixie already supports the latest
Open Standards for data with open
Telemetry the Telemetry data with Pixie
is stored in two different location one
is in your cluster's memory which lives
for up to 24 hours and you can choose to
export it to a long-term external
storage to a fully supported open
Telemetry platform with pixie's plug-in
system all you need is an OT LP endpoint
and your
set if you are already using neic today
you can use the guided installation and
choose pixie which will automatically
register pixie with the plug-in system
and you'll be able to purist the data
long for the long-term storage in neur
this hybrid storage model allows you to
actively debug your active kubernetes
incidents with the rich set of telemetry
data available in memory while also
saving turns of cost by choosing to
export what Telemetry data is going to
be helpful to you for a long-term
storage with that I want to conclude and
ask you to come explore pixie and be a
